End of an era: All the road cycling greats retiring this year

As the 2023 road racing season ends, the peloton waves goodbye to some major players, from French cult icon Thibaut Pinot to one of the greatest of all time Annemiek van Vleuten. 

A host of heavy hitters will hang up their spurs at the end of the year, or have already done so. 

Here’s a rundown of the names we’ll be missing on the road next year…

Thibaut Pinot

French legend Thibaut Pinot crossed the finish line for the last time at Il Lombardia just last week, the Monument he won in 2018. Pinot’s heart-on-his-sleeve style and succession of near misses, injuries, and abandons just when he looked close to winning a Tour de France earned him a devoted following of ‘Ultras’.

‘Sometimes I feel like I’m more popular than I am talented. There are days when I wish I got less love and more wins,’ he revealed in the ‘Tour de France: Unchained’ documentary released last year. 

The fans came out in force in Bergamo for his final race, as well as lining the roads on Stage 20 of this year’s Tour, which was his real last hurrah. 

His solo ascent to the top of Le Petit Ballon rolled back the years and while he couldn’t hold off eventual stage winner Tadej Pogačar and the yellow jersey group, he crossed the line in a very respectable seventh place. To the crowds of boozed-up Ultras cheering him on he may as well have won it, anyway. 

Over his career Pinot won stages at all three Grand Tours as well as third step on the overall podium and best young rider at the Tour in 2014. 

Nearly a decade later he was King of the Mountains at the Giro d’Italia in 2023, rounding off a storied career in style. He’ll now enjoy the quiet life on his farm in the Vosges region while French Grand Tour hopes pass on to the new generation including Groupama-FDJ teammate Lenny Martinez.

Annemiek van Vleuten

Dutch superstar Annemiek van Vleuten has had a remarkable career that few – if any – will be able to surpass. Her list of achievements could fill a book: 104 UCI wins on the road, mountain bike and in time-trials, Liège-Bastogne-Liège, Strade Bianche, and the Tour of Flanders.

She cruised to an astonishing five Giro d’Italia Donne victories, three at La Vuelta Femenina (consecutively, in its changing form), and the Tour de France Femmes, doing the calendar triple in 2022. 

A fourth place at this year’s Tour de France Femmes was a disappointing result for her but in no way negates a career few could even dream of. The list goes on: European Championships gold and the double of World Championships road and time-trial golds – twice. Oh, and Olympic time-trial gold in Tokyo 2021. 

Van Vleuten’s last major race was the 2023 TdFF, where onlookers witnessed a changing of the guard as compatriot Demi Vollering came of age and blew the field to pieces to win. 

It’ll be strange seeing a start line without Van Vleuten’s presence, but it’s nice of her to give some other riders a chance…

Peter Sagan

It’s almost impossible to imagine a Tour de France without Peter Sagan, either omnipresent in green during the mid-2010s or otherwise livening up the peloton with wheelies on Alpe d’Huez. 

Sagan will call time on road racing at the end of this year, although he’ll still be in action on the mountain bike, where he started as a junior and plans to finish his senior career, aiming for the Paris Olympics next year.

The Slovakian won a record seven points classifications at the Tour de France – five in a row from 2012 to 2016 – as well as eighteen Grand Tour stages, his fair share of Classics including the Tour of Flanders and Paris-Roubaix, and even the general classification at the Tour of California. And of course he won three World Championships in a row, an unbelievable feat.

His palmarès is all the more impressive for his sprinting successes in an era largely dominated by the likes of Mark Cavendish, Marcel Kittel and Andre Greipel. He really can do it all. 

Nathan Van Hooydonck

Most riders on this list are old-timers but there’s a sad exception in the form of Nathan Van Hooydonck, a Jumbo-Visma super-domestique who has been forced to retire at the age of just 27.

The Dutchman was involved in a car crash shortly after the Tour of Britain last month when he suffered a cardiac incident that caused him to lose control of the vehicle he was driving. 

The outcome could have been a lot worse but fortunately he made a full recovery. Doctors detected a heart muscle anomaly and fitted him with an ICD.

Van Hooydonck told Dutch media, ‘I don’t really remember anything about the accident. I do remember the sadness, because even before the doctors told me, I already knew that my career was over.’ 

Greg Van Avermaet

Greg Van Avermaet – appropriately named after cycling great Greg LeMond – rode his last race at Paris-Tours earlier this year.  

The Belgian all-rounder had a fantastic few seasons in the mid-2010s, including beating Rafał Majka and Jakob Fulgsang in a three-man sprint for 2016 Olympic Road Race gold. 

He held his own in stage races and Grand Tours – wearing the yellow jersey in 2016 and 2018 – but was better known for victories in the Classics, peaking with Paris-Roubaix in 2017.

His racing breakthrough was way back in 2008, where he took the points jersey at the Vuelta a España ahead of the likes of eventual maillot rojo Alberto Contador and Alejandro Valverde.

And honourable mentions… 

Tony Gallopin – the last Frenchman to wear yellow on Bastille Day, in 2014 – bowed out after a 16-year career at Paris-Tours in October, where he won the 2008 Under-23 edition. But he won’t vanish completely as he’ll move into a directeur sportif role for former team Lotto-Dstny. 

Two-time Time-Trial World Champion and winner of stages at all three Grand Tours Rohan Dennis is hanging up his cleats at the tender age of 33. He was the key domestique in Tao Geoghegan Hart’s Giro d’Italia win. Former South African National Champion and serial Grand Tour stage winner Daryl Impey will also retire at the end of the year. He became the first African rider to wear the Tour de France yellow jersey in 2013.

British rider Hannah Barnes is calling it a day aged 30, and four real veterans of the sport, 40-year-olds Dries Devenyns and Luis Léon Sanchez, and one-team men Jos van Emden and Imanol Erviti round off the list of cyclists leaving the pro peloton at the season’s close. 

But arguably one of the most significant retirements of 2023 is one that isn’t actually happening after all, with sprinting great Mark Cavendish postponing his just last week by promising ‘just one more year’ on the road.
